StudyObjective: To explore the interaction between conflict resolution processes and memory encoding in MTLE patients and healthy controls using a face-word Stroop paradigm and an incidental memory task.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants viewed male and female faces overlaid with congruent or incongruent words (man or woman) and had to indicate the gender of the face by pressing a button. The task aimed to investigate the effects of response conflict on memory encoding.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task used an event-related design with 120 trials (60 male and 60 female faces). Faces were displayed for 1500ms with a pseudo-exponentially distributed SOA of 5000ms (75%), 7500ms (17%), and 10000ms (8%). Trials were presented in a randomized order with a 50% probability for congruent and incongruent conditions. A black fixation dot was displayed throughout the task to ensure accurate fixation.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants were presented with previously seen faces and novel faces, and had to indicate whether they had seen the face before or not using a four-point scale (definitely old, probably old, probably new, definitely new).
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: The task was conducted outside the MRI scanner, with faces displayed for 2000ms followed by a 2000ms inter-trial interval. Participants rated their recognition of the faces using a four-button response system.
TaskMetrics: Recognition rates (definitely old and probably old)
